title: 105_hr2175
content: The "Foreign Oil Displacement Act" aims to reduce the US dependence on imported oil by promoting a synthetic fuels industry using domestic resources. Financial incentives are needed to support the development of facilities for commercial-scale production of synthetic fuels. The "Foreign Oil Displacement Act" promotes a synthetic fuels industry using domestic resources. It introduces the carbonaceous fuels facility credit, providing a 28% credit for qualified investments in carbonaceous fuels conversion facilities. The carbonaceous fuels conversion facility is defined as a facility owned by the taxpayer, depreciable under section 167, with a useful life of at least 4 years. The carbonaceous fuels conversion facility must be owned by the taxpayer, depreciable under section 167, and have a useful life of at least 4 years. Special rules apply for sale-leasebacks where the facility is sold and leased back within 3 months for a period of not less than 12 years. The taxpayer must own the carbonaceous fuels conversion facility, which must be depreciable under section 167 and have a useful life of at least 4 years. Special rules apply for sale-leasebacks of the facility. The term 'qualified fuel' is defined in clause (iv) of subparagraph (A) as per section 29(c), with additional inclusions like standard anthracite, peat, and byproducts from coal. The curr_chunk discusses qualified investments and progress expenditures related to carbonaceous fuels conversion facilities. Qualified investments refer to the basis of such facilities placed in service during a taxable year, while progress expenditures increase the qualified investment amount for taxpayers who have made a specific election. The curr_chunk defines progress expenditure property as property under construction by the taxpayer that cannot be completed in less than 18 months and is expected to qualify as a carbonaceous fuels conversion facility. Qualified progress expenditures are the aggregate of such expenditures for the taxable year. For self-constructed property, qualified progress expenditures are the amount properly chargeable to capital account during the taxable year. For non-self-constructed property, qualified progress expenditures are the amount paid to another person for construction during the taxable year. Other definitions are provided for this subsection. The term 'self-constructed property' refers to property where more than half of the construction expenditures are made directly by the taxpayer. 'Non-self-constructed property' is property that does not meet this criteria. 'Construction' includes reconstruction and erection in this context. Section 50 of the tax code is amended to allow for the sale or assignment of unused carbonaceous fuels facility credits, with regulations set by the Secretary. Sellers or assignors remain liable for penalties or interest, and the basis of the facility is not adjusted due to the sale or assignment. SEC. 4. EXEMPTION FROM MANUFACTURERS EXCISE TAX ON FUELS. The amendment exempts qualified carbonaceous fuel from the manufacturers excise tax on fuels for a specified period. Qualified carbonaceous fuel is defined as fuel produced by a carbonaceous fuels conversion facility. The amendment exempts qualified carbonaceous fuel from certain taxes for a limited period.
